drawer_footer_note: These insights are based on connected play data, optional collection imports, and long-term patterns. Ownership and play are treated as distinct signals.

archetypes.name: Completionist
archetypes.why: You tend to see games through to the end. When you commit to a playthrough, you're more likely than most players to reach credits, final trophies, or end-state milestones instead of drifting away.

signals.label: Trophies & achievements
signals.copy: You frequently complete structured goals.

signals.label: Play progress
signals.copy: Many sessions reach late-game states.

signals.label: Ownership
signals.copy: Owning a game does not imply completion.

strength_tiers.emerging: You're starting to close the loop on more games than before.
strength_tiers.strong: Finishing games is a consistent pattern for you.
strength_tiers.core: Completion is a defining part of how you play.

archetypes.name: Explorer
archetypes.why: You sample widely, follow curiosity, and enjoy seeing what a game has to offer without feeling obligated to finish everything. Breadth matters more than checkmarks.

signals.label: Library diversity
signals.copy: You touch many different titles and genres.

signals.label: Short-to-mid sessions
signals.copy: Play often happens in bursts rather than long arcs.

signals.label: Trophies & achievements
signals.copy: Completion signals are secondary.

strength_tiers.core: Your play history is defined by curiosity.

archetypes.name: Era Keeper
archetypes.header: You're anchored to a specific gaming era.
archetypes.why: Your collection and play history cluster strongly around particular hardware generations or time periods. Those eras aren't just nostalgic — they're where your taste lives.

signals.label: Era concentration
signals.copy: A large share of your games come from the same eras.

signals.label: Ownership
signals.copy: Collections reinforce era focus.

signals.label: Longevity
signals.copy: You return to these eras over time.

strength_tiers.emerging: Certain eras are starting to stand out.
strength_tiers.core: Era identity defines your gaming history.

archetypes.name: Nostalgist
archetypes.header: You return to the games that shaped you.
archetypes.why: You revisit familiar titles, remasters, or series entries across platforms and years. Games aren't just experiences — they're touchstones.

signals.label: Replay behavior
signals.copy: Multiple play sessions across time.

signals.label: Multi-platform ownership
signals.copy: Same titles appear on different systems.

signals.label: Time gaps
signals.copy: Revisits span years, not weeks.

strength_tiers.emerging: You're starting to revisit old favorites.
strength_tiers.core: Nostalgia strongly shapes what you play.

archetypes.name: Strategist
archetypes.header: You prefer systems that reward mastery.
archetypes.why: You gravitate toward games that demand planning, optimization, or tactical thinking. Progress comes from understanding systems, not reflex alone.

signals.label: Genre affinity (strategy, tactics, RPGs)
signals.copy: Your play history clusters around deeper systems.

signals.label: High-difficulty achievements
signals.copy: You pursue challenging goals when they're meaningful.

signals.label: Deep-session play
signals.copy: You stick with games long enough to learn the systems.

strength_tiers.core: Mastery is central to how you enjoy games.

archetypes.name: Archivist
archetypes.why: You don't just own games — you organize, categorize, and preserve them. Your collection reflects care, memory, and long-term curation.

signals.label: Owned titles
signals.copy: Your library is substantial.

signals.label: Organization (tags, shelves, notes)
signals.copy: You add structure that makes the collection usable.

signals.label: Acquisition timeline
signals.copy: Your collecting history builds over time.

archetypes.guardrail_note: Ownership signals identity and care, not play or completion.

archetypes.name: Variant Hunter
archetypes.header: You seek versions, not just titles.
archetypes.why: You collect multiple editions, regions, or formats of the same game. Differences matter — packaging, platform, release context.

signals.label: Duplicate titles (multi-edition)
signals.copy: You collect more than one version of the same game.

signals.label: Regional variants
signals.copy: Different regions appear across your collection.

signals.label: Edition metadata
signals.copy: Your library includes distinct releases beyond a single SKU.

strength_tiers.core: Variant tracking is a core behavior.

archetypes.name: Hardware Historian
archetypes.header: You care about the machines, not just the games.
archetypes.why: Your interest extends to consoles, peripherals, and oddball systems. You see hardware as part of gaming history, not just a delivery method.

signals.label: Console ownership
signals.copy: You track systems as part of the hobby.

signals.label: Accessories / oddball systems
signals.copy: Your library extends beyond standard setups.

signals.label: Era spread
signals.copy: Your hardware interest spans generations.

strength_tiers.core: Hardware history is part of your identity.

archetypes.name: Curator
archetypes.why: You actively decide what belongs in your collection or backlog. Lists, filters, and organization matter as much as play itself.

signals.label: Lists & tags
signals.copy: You organize games into meaningfully defined sets.

signals.label: Ratings / notes
signals.copy: You capture taste, not just activity.

signals.label: Ownership + play balance
signals.copy: Your library reflects choices, not just accumulation.
